head.title: Van Drivers for Disabled Strike for Better Wages

hedline.hl1: Van Drivers for Disabled Strike for Better Wages

abstract.p: Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go go on strike over wages and medical benefits; their employer, Laidlaw Transportation, uses other employees and taxis to compensate (M)

block.p: Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to the doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go went on strike yesterday over wages and medical benefits.

Their employer, Laidlaw Transportation of Pennsauken, which contracts with New Jersey Transit to carry people who cannot use regular buses or trains, was able to serve 150 people using other employees and local taxis, said Stu Livensparger, a Laidlaw district manager. The service is provided under the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act in Camden, Burlington, Cumberland, Gloucester and Salem Counties.
Sixty van drivers who take 180 disabled people in southern New Jersey to the doctor, to work and wherever else they need to go went on strike yesterday over wages and medical benefits.

Their employer, Laidlaw Transportation of Pennsauken, which contracts with New Jersey Transit to carry people who cannot use regular buses or trains, was able to serve 150 people using other employees and local taxis, said Stu Livensparger, a Laidlaw district manager. The service is provided under the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act in Camden, Burlington, Cumberland, Gloucester and Salem Counties.

The drivers, who make $6 an hour, voted to join Local 676 of the teamsters' union last June and are trying to negotiate a contract, said Joseph Uchniat, business agent for Local 676. The company has rejected the drivers' demand to reduce their health insurance co-payments, Mr. Uchniat said. Mr. Livensparger would say only that the company's offer was fair.
